data.text: @jaimeburchardt I honestly can't believe that this was a discussion I had with someone.
@lhbizness This is the most fucked up thread I’ve seen and it’s MONDAY
@hausofmugIer @lhbizness Hi. You're an asshat. I am blocking you. End of conversation. Buh-bye now.
@lhbizness So if he were not a famous director, would anyone be arguing that he IS white? No, especially if he were applying for asylum or had committed a crime. Then he would be too brown

@liamrulz I mean, given the current state of American racism and xenophobia, for anyone to attempt to usurp a Mexican filmmaker and his success as a success of "whiteness" seems an unforgivable act of colonization and erasure.

@lhbizness Oh did it come across like I was correcting you? My bad. 
Within the US white Latinx folks who have accents and Spanish sounding last names allow us to see how whiteness is made up! He is white or not white as it affirms white people's self perceptions

@liamrulz I understand that - I was simply responding to the attempt to categorize del Toro with Nolan or Cooper, which seems to ignore his Mexican/Latinx identity and historical and contemporary marginalization within American society.
@lhbizness Wow, I am UNSPEAKABLY angry right now.

@lhbizness Latinx communities are racially diverse and then in the US we get combined into one homogenous idea of Latinx when in reality that is a term describe many racial and ethnic identities. 
However in many of our communities anti blackness persists and thus whiteness does as well
(The overlap of race and ethnicity always get a bit dicey and I'm not gonna go any further with this, but it does seem very offensive to erase del Toro's Mexican-ness.)
